bug.short_desc: Vertical layout is weird on Extensions page

long_desc.thetext:
The Extensions/Extension Points pages of the plug-in manifest editor have toolbar buttons on the top right of the page that toggle the orientation (horizontal/vertical).
The vertical orientation looks weird, particularly on the Extensions page that also has a Body Text section.
I suggest removing these two buttons, as the horizontal orientation is the only desirable setting.

Created an attachment (id=46691) org.eclipse.pde.ui.patch
left the option for future users of PDEMasterDetailsBlock the ability to get those wonder layout options
Thanks Chris.

bug.short_desc: Change order of fields for extensions

long_desc.thetext:
When an extension is selected on the Extensions page of the plug-in editor, three fields appear to the right: ID, Name and Point.
Since Point is the only required attribute, it should be listed first.
Created an attachment (id=46690) org.eclipse.pde.ui.patch
Chris resurfaced :)

bug.short_desc: [open type] Ask for opening project if source file is in a closed project

long_desc.thetext:
If you use a hyperlink/Open Type to open a class which is in a closed project, the class editor is opened and tells me that the source file is not available. Wouldn't it be better if the workbench asks me if I want to open the project and then opens the source file instead of showing me the class editor?
Tell me what you think. If you're interested, i'll try to provide a patch for this as well.

We don't know whats's in closed projects. By design all resources in closed projects are released.
Open type can only show you types from open projects. If a type with the same names also exists in a closed project is - in general- accidental. I don't think we should build a feature around that.

Imagine a workspace with 2 projects: ProjectA (open) which depends on ProjectB (closed).
You're coding in ProjectA, see a Type you don't know, hold Ctrl and click on it. Because the type is in ProjectB (which is closed), you get the classviewer. If you have about 50-60 projects, most of them closed, you need to open each project before you click on your unkown type. I think this is really worth to add.

bug.short_desc: [misc] Replace Class Viewer with Java Editor if source is available when opening a project

long_desc.thetext:
If you open a type which is in a closed project, the class viewer isn shown. When the class viewer is opened and you open the project again, the classviewer is closed and nothing else happens. It would be great if the class editor is closed and a java editor with the sourcefile is opened.
This enhancement could be a fallback for #151503

bug.short_desc: [content assist] field names in setters or constructors are not completed by content assist if to be qualified with this

long_desc.thetext: Tom, please comment

Interesting - I wasn't aware of the qualified proposals. We should of course support this.
JavaCompletionProposal needs to special case ::isValidPrefix.

In fact that has worked already in releases prior to 3.1 I would suspect there was some logic to have the "this" qualifier automatically prepended for the case that parameter and field name are equal. This code might have been removed and alternatively the "this." qualifier was added to the replacement string. Normally, there is no need for the qualifier in the list if member variables can easily be identified by associated image. Also, if no initial prefix (like k in the sample) is typed before invoking completion, the qualified proposal is automatically removed from the list after typing the first characters (if not "this")

bug.short_desc: Weird errors in Eclipse log during automatic update search

long_desc.thetext:
Error: "Digest could not be parsed:Unable to retrieve remote reference "http://download.eclipse.org/updates/3.2/digest.zip". [Server returned HTTP response code: "404 Not Found" for URL: http://download.eclipse.org/updates/3.2/digest.zip.]" in org.eclipse.update.core
-- Error Log -- Date: Sat Jul 22 01:02:19 EDT 2006 Message: Digest could not be parsed:Unable to retrieve remote reference "http://download.eclipse.org/updates/3.2/digest.zip". [Server returned HTTP response code: "404 Not Found" for URL: http://download.eclipse.org/updates/3.2/digest.zip.] Severity: Error Plugin ID: org.eclipse.update.core Stack Trace: no stack trace available

there is nothing wrong here what it means is that site.xml point to digest being at http://download.eclipse.org/updates/3.2/ (update adds digest.zip) but it was not found thus we will fall back to the old way update used to work i.e. without digest.
If there is nothing wrong, this message should not go to the error log. Please find some other way to notify user about this. Error log is a really bad place to dump this stuff into.
It is reported because site.xml is wrong. So, it is site problem and it needs to be logged in the log. However, there is no problem in update manager.

(In reply to comment #3) > It is reported because site.xml is wrong. So, it is site problem and it needs > to be logged in the log. However, there is no problem in update manager.
The point is that error should be presented to the user. Log is useless in such cases and this logging is just making unnecessary noise.

bug.short_desc: [javadoc] NotDeleted in DefaultPositionUpdater appears to be inacurrate

long_desc.thetext:
I have created a small document with a couple of positions and a few text edit operations.
Here is an example: Doc text:12345 Position: 0,2 (so 12) Position: 1,1 (so 2) DeleteEdit(0,2)
The delete operation covers the area of the 2 position and according to the rules of the defaultpositionupdater,they should be deleted (or marked as such)
Here are the results: Document Content: 12345 New positions added: Offset: 0, Length: 2, Descr:12,Deleted:false Offset: 1, Length: 1, Descr:2,Deleted:false Positions left: Offset: 0, Length: 0, Descr:12,Deleted:false Offset: 0, Length: 0, Descr:2,Deleted:false Document Content: 345
When debugging the app it seems that the culprit is in notDeleted where the following test occurs: if (fOffset < fPosition.offset && (fPosition.offset + fPosition.length < fOffset + fLength)) {
To work as expected the test should be changed to : if (fOffset <= fPosition.offset && (fPosition.offset + fPosition.length <= fOffset + fLength)) {
Is that a fair assessment of the situation of am I missing something here?

Clearly a position that completely covers a section of text, does actually covers it.
I understand that others might have taken advantage of that shortcoming or worked around it (like me now), but this can't just be closed. Either it is fixed to match the documentation or the documentation is fixed to explain the deviation from the what "completely contains" really means or that you have a new zero length position that you should watch for and delete yourself.

(In reply to comment #2) > Clearly a position that completely covers a section of text, does actually > cover it.
That statemement is a tautology. However, it does not add anything to the definition of "completely contains" that is used in DefaultPositionUpdater. "Contains" may sometimes indeed mean "cover" or "span", which I would interpret in your fashion. But it can also have the meaning of "encompass", or "envelop", which may under a certain viewpoint require the container to extend not only to the boundaries of the containee, but to extend over its boundaries by a non-empty amount. This latter viewpoint of "strict containment" is implied by the implementation of DefaultPositionUpdater.
> Either it is > fixed to match the documentation or the documentation is fixed to explain the > deviation from the what "completely contains" really means
You seem to be quite sure that your interpretation of "completely contain" is the right and only one...
I agree that the documentation should be more precise, however. Added some clarification > 2006724. Marking as fixed.
I also found a deviation from the spec'ed behavior documented in bug 151591.
*** Bug 178514 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: FTP problems with symlinks

long_desc.thetext: I've got a website with some folders connected by symlinks (ln -s ...) that can created under linux. When I try to import this site by ftp into eclipse the file list contains a huge account of folders that doesn't exists, only implicid by the symlink. For example: /downloads/a, /downloads/donwloads/a, /downloads/downloads/donwloads/a, /downloads/downloads/donwloads/downloads/a etc. Is there a possibility to stop the ftp file listing when recognizing a symlink instead of showing all possible folder listings?
The FTP/WebDAV plugins are not officially supported but patches will be gratefully accepted.

We are in the process of removing the Team FTP/WebDAV feature since the DSDP Target management component (http://www.eclipse.org/dsdp/tm/) provides complimentary functionality and will be shipping as part of Europa. Although the feature will not be part of Europa, we have provided a link to a 3.3 compatible version of the feature at http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Team_Development.

bug.short_desc: Provide an oAW project creation wizard

long_desc.thetext: I found it quite a hassle to make a project work with oAW. In the same way you can create an EMF project that is configured with all dependencies, I suggest a project creation wizard, that creates a project with the oAW nature (which you already have) and correct dependencies. When I created my oAW project I added all jars I found in the plug-ins. This works but is certainly not the minimal set of jars. Which jars are really needed?

FIXED
oAW 4.1 provides a project creation wizard as well as wizards for creating oAW files.
File/New/Other openArchitectureWare CheckFile Generator project Workflow file xPand Template xTend File Xtext Projects
The project is set up with minimal dependencies.
Fantastic!

bug.short_desc: [DetachedView] Multi Monitor support: sash-based detached windows

long_desc.thetext:
Currently the only way to outsource tabs which are synchronized with another view in the workbench is to use detached views which are not as organizable as the main workbench window.
My request is to add a subwindow which can be moved to another monitor but still keep it synchronized with the main one like a detached window is atm.
Maybe an example:
I would like to have my java editor view on monitor #1 but the outline, package explorer and hierarchy (which all are linked to the editor) on the second monitor in a single, organizeable window instead of a bunch of detached popup windows. Of course the layout of that sub-window should be stored too, this way developing with multiple monitors might be more efficient.

Absolutely! We've been looking for a while (i.e. I started during 3.2) at making the Detached Window capable of supporting a PartSashContainer rather than a simple View Stack. I can't promise anything but this is certainly on my personal list of 'good things'(tm).
Paul, once you come up for non-keybinding related air we should take some time to see if we can come up with a viable story for this as far as the Perspective is concerned...
Any chance that this will make it to the target milestone?
This is looking less and less likely for 3.3...my plate is almost as full as the one I had on the holidays...;-)
This -must- be part of the component framework story...
Just wanted to note that this is part of my Summer of Code project (http://wiki.eclipse.org/Improve_multi-monitor_support) and I'm currently working on this.
I think a "Yay!" is appropriate in that case ;)
Ben, bear in mind that if you introduce a SashContainer into the mix you'll have to handle min/max within it. What are your current plans?

I wondered if we should also have a concept of min/max in detached windows. On the one side, I think that's a big pain to have all these concepts in detached windows (3.3 min/max story etc) but on the other side it would be very handy to have it available. Have to look how much work it is. Eric, do you think of any other problems/improvements which could be done as part of this task?

Ben, you can't get away with -not- doing it I think. Once we introduce multiple 'panes' into the DW folks will intuitively expect it to work the same...
That being said, clients have been asking for this capability for some time (so most might be willing to live without min/max for a release...or two...;-).
One thing that I haven't had time to scope out is whether the new DW could be based on a cut-down WorkbenchWindow rather than an augmented DetachedWindow (i.e. no Editor Area, CoolBar, PerspectiveSwitcher or basic trim like the status line). It would have the advantage of handling zoom automatically and it -might- be possible to do it with a 'custom' perspective type. I don't know how invested you are in the current code but it might be worth a look...

From a user perspective it's pretty simple: The window should basically add screen real estate to the main workbench window and provide all functionality that can be moved within the main window: this is view-tabs, toolbars and editor windows. The perspective switcher, the menus and the status bar can't be moved and thus don't have to be moved outside the main window either. It should be maximizable of course (fitting/moving windows that should gobble up as much space as possible is a PITA), maybe even fullscreen-able since all necessary controls are on the main window itself.
Yes, i know i'm asking for much here, but i'm just describing the ideal situation ;)

Eric, i thought about that idea some weeks ago and i think i'll give it a try. Could get very interesting to have a WorkbenchWindow "light" as replacement for the DetachedWindow. Will inform you here about my progress.
the8472, come on - tell us your name ;-) I think we need to split your request on several bugs: Toolbars are not yet movable: see bug 179043 Editors are not yet movable: see bug 8886 Toolbars but without Perspective Switcher: see bug 56625 (btw: we should remove the WONTFIX) Maximize DW: see bug 120910 Fullscreen: needs 37031 and bug 171398
As most - eh - all bugs are part of my project, I think all relevant parts of the request are covered ;-)

Ben, watch out...you may be over-comitting here. Allowing Toolbars (and, presumably a 'main' menu) is gonna get you a true can of worms. Our command management is one of the most complex areas of the workbench and extending it our to 'satellite' windows will -not- be trivial...some questions:
Which main ToolBars / Menus should be shown?
How do we manage the general command context when it's shared across multiple shells? (see Bug 195672; we can't even manage it now)?
If you add Editors into the picture then I think we've come full circle...this is a new workbench window; not a 'satellite'. What wouldn't be allowed in the satellite windows?

Eric, you'r right with watching at those problems. But I've never said to implement Toolbars/Menus in Detached Windows. Just wanted to tell "the8472" where he could look at all the bugs regarding his requests. Especially bug 179043 is a gray area which I would like to look at but don't know yet in which way this could be possible. The bug is about floating toolbars and not toolbars in detached windows (may be the same problems there - ok).
I think before thinking of these areas we should have a look at a basic implementation of a lightweight WW which replaces the DW. If I encounter bigger problems in that area, I'll ping you :)
Ben, thanks for the clarification. It's not that I don't -want- them there, it's just that in our current world we might have 'issues'...;-).

Hrmhrm, as i stated above the functionality i described (adding screen area and keeping all main workbench functionality) is just a wish, something less would do too for sure if it's more realistic, such as sashview(s) + fullscreen capability for detached windows for example.

bug.short_desc: [KeyBindings] Editor scoped actions sometimes execute against wrong editor

long_desc.thetext:
We noticed during plugin development that occasionally a command bound to an action contributed through org.eclipse.ui.editorActions/editorContribution would execute against the wrong editor (potentially an editor that has been long since closed).
The problem is as follows:
When the editor part is activated, an IHandlerActivation containing a LegacyHandlerWrapper with an EditorPluginAction is submitted to HandlerAuthority. As long as this handler is the active handler for the command everything works as it should.
However, when the workbench window is created, an IHandlerActivation containing an ActionDelegateHandlerProxy is passed to HandlerAuthority. On first use, the IEditorActionDelegate is initialized and the active editor is provided to the delegate. However, thereafter, it's never updated so if the delegate is run again, the delegate will still have the reference to the old (possibly long dead) editor.
With a source priority of 4210688 compared with a source priority of 67113984 for the part-specific handler, it should never be executed though. The problem is EvaluationResultCacheComparator. Since it operates on IEvaluationResultCache which does not implement Comparable, Util.compare(Object, Object) is called instead of Util.compare(Comparable, Comparable). The result is that the IHandlerActivation SortedSet in HandlerAuthority ends up in a more or less arbitrary order and an arbitrary handler wins the conflict resolution.
The Comparator in HandlerAuthority needs to operate on IHandlerAuthority instead of IEvaluationResultCache.

If you use the trace options for org.eclipse.ui for handlers, you should see the handlers that are actually compared for any given resolveConflicts(). I don't believe the order in the set matters, since the entire set is iterated through.
If you give the specific commandId, gov.wicourts.querytool.commands.parseCommand, then you should have more detailed information.
org.eclipse.ui/debug=true org.eclipse.ui/trace/handlers=true org.eclipse.ui/trace/handlers.verbose=true org.eclipse.ui/trace/handlers.verbose.commandId=gov.wicourts.querytool.commands.parseCommand
PW

Created an attachment (id=46715) Tracing file demonstrating problem
Attached is a trace file demonstrating the problem. It's the result of allowing a max of one open editor and then clicking back and forth between two files. The set of potential handlers is the same as in comment #1.
Line 22 is the first resolveConflicts() which chooses the wrong handler. Line 47 shows an example of resolveConflicts() choosing the right handler again(arbitrarily, due to the SortedSet which isn't really sorted). Line 127 is resolveConflicts() making the wrong choice again.
Line 128 is our IEditorActionDelegate requerying the workbench for the active editor when it notices it's active editor reference is stale.
The rest of the file is more of the same, but I've included it for additional context.

(In reply to comment #4) > > Line 22 is the first resolveConflicts() which chooses the wrong handler.
Hmmm, from line 21 to 25 I see: --------------
HANDLERS >>> resolveConflicts: eval: HandlerActivation(commandId=gov.wicourts.querytool.commands.parseCommand,handler=ActionDelegateHandlerProxy(null,gov.wicourts.querytool.eclipse.actions.ParseQueryAction),expression=AndExpression(LegacyEditorContributionExpression(gov.wicourts.querytool.eclipse.editor.QueryEditor,org.eclipse.ui.internal.WorkbenchWindow@133f6dd),WorkbenchWindowExpression(org.eclipse.ui.internal.WorkbenchWindow@133f6dd)),sourcePriority=4210688) HANDLERS >>> resolveConflicts: eval: HandlerActivation(commandId=gov.wicourts.querytool.commands.parseCommand,handler=ActionDelegateHandlerProxy(null,gov.wicourts.querytool.eclipse.actions.ParseQueryObjectAction),expression=WorkbenchWindowExpression(org.eclipse.ui.internal.WorkbenchWindow@133f6dd),sourcePriority=16384) HANDLERS >>> Resolved conflict detected. The following activation won: HANDLERS >>> HandlerActivation(commandId=gov.wicourts.querytool.commands.parseCommand,handler=ActionDelegateHandlerProxy(null,gov.wicourts.querytool.eclipse.actions.ParseQueryAction),expression=AndExpression(LegacyEditorContributionExpression(gov.wicourts.querytool.eclipse.editor.QueryEditor,org.eclipse.ui.internal.WorkbenchWindow@133f6dd),WorkbenchWindowExpression(org.eclipse.ui.internal.WorkbenchWindow@133f6dd)),sourcePriority=4210688) --------------
Based on that it looks correct that it picked 4210688 over 16384.
On line 127, it also picked 4210688, which is the correct priority to pick.
I'm still investigating fixing that EvaluationResultCacheComparator (it's not complicated, but high risk :-) It looks to be part of a half-complete (and hence wrong) optimization - if the set is sorted highest to lowest, then the first 2 handlers will tell the HandlerAuthority if there's a conflict or a winner.
PW
The right choice had a source priority of 67113984 (see comment #1), but resolveConflicts() broke out of the loop before it got that far.

(In reply to comment #6)
Ah, drops out of the loop so I don't see the guy expected to win.
I'll run some tests on the EvaluationResultCacheComparator.
PW

Created an attachment (id=46824) Just check for Comparable
Not elegent, but it would sort the set as per the optimization.
PW

Created an attachment (id=46849) Update to use that comparable
This update for comparable uses compareTo(*) to get the natural order, but equality is still left to identity.
PW

Just updating the comparator doesn't solve the problem ... the handler activation order + the sort optimization is still incorrect.
PW

Created an attachment (id=46938) activation optimization v03
Corrected the handler optimization so that it 1) the handler activations sort from lowest to highest 2) the EvaluationResultCacheComparator sorts from highest to lowest 3) resolveConflicts() checks at least 2 enabled handlers to find either a conflict or a winner
PW

I've released these changes into HEAD >20060728
After some more testing, I'll consider them for 3.2.1
PW
Paul, the change in HandlerAuthority makes me nervous. Should we spend some time together on this, maybe when I'm back next week?

(In reply to comment #13) > Paul, the change in HandlerAuthority makes me nervous.
BTW, I am not saying that the fix is wrong, it's just an uneasy feeling.

Created an attachment (id=47527) activation optimization v04 - inverted patch for 3.2.1
This is the inverted patch (don't ask me why :-) for 3.2.1
PW

Released into 3.2.1 >20060809
PW

Released tests into HEAD >20060814
PW
fixed in 3.2.1

attachment.desc: activation optimization v04 - inverted patch for 3.2.1

bug.short_desc: XLF toolchain fails to create configuration folders (Debug and Release)

long_desc.thetext: XLF toolchain fails to create makefiles (and build folder) to build a configuration. Thus a XLF cannot be used for a managed make project.
There was an error in the XLF toolchain, fixed in version 1.4 of org.eclipse.photran.managedbuilder.gnu.ui (plugin.xml).

bug.short_desc: Installation dependencies do not all work

long_desc.thetext:
Download the zip and select it as a local update site
Select a single feature, like the javascript.feature from ATF. Click the select dependencies button. It does not select Rhino, as it should. The feature.xml ought to specify the feature-level requirements, I think. We should review these before the next milestone. (The syntax checker works on the Mac, btw :)

ATF is now installed as one feature and has dependencies on Rhino and xpcom. The ATF feature doesn't require the Zimbra runtime feature to be installed, since a developer may not want to use Zimbra. The Dojo and Rico runtime features are automatically installed since they are package with ATF, but will not work unless the developer manually copies in a version of the source for the runtime into the plugin.
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991

bug.short_desc: [validation] Incorrect CHKJ4019W web.xml validation warning

long_desc.thetext:
The following in my web.xml shows incorrect Warnings in the problems view:
<resource-ref id="ResRef_1"> <res-ref-name>jdbc/MyDS</res-ref-name> <res-type>javax.sql.DataSource</res-type> <res-auth>Container</res-auth> </resource-ref>
The warning is:
CHKJ4019W: Invalid res-sharing-scope; valid values are "Shareable" or "Unshareable".
It is my understanding that the <res-sharing-scope> element is optional at all times and therefore a validator should not even throw a warning about it not being present. Which is the problem here.
When it is specified, yes the valdator must check that its either of the two values "Shareable" or "Unshareable".
<resource-ref id="ResRef_1"> <res-ref-name>jdbc/MyDS</res-ref-name> <res-type>javax.sql.DataSource</res-type> <res-auth>Container</res-auth> <res-sharing-scope>Shareable</res-sharing-scope> </resource-ref>

The problem seems to be in the EMFModel, ResourceRef, which is not distinguishing the value being set to invalid or value not existing at all, the API on ResourceRef isSetResSharingScope() is set to false in both cases, and getResSharingScope().getName() is set to "Shareable".
The validator is depending on the above 2 API's to report the problem.
Since the fix will be required in ResourceRef, which could potentially cause regressions in other places and the problem is not too severe, (it is only a warning) i am deferring this defect to 2.0

bug.short_desc: Fortran editor won't set breakpoint

long_desc.thetext: A breakpoint can't be set in a Fortran file. The editor puts up the "Add Bookmark" dialog when one double clicks in the left border of the editor.
Workaround (for me) is to right click in the left border column, and select "toggle breakpoint"
Fixed on or before 3.1 beta 2
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991

bug.short_desc: [SSH2] cvs extssh connection method is not defined in plugin.xml

long_desc.thetext: I see that cvs pserver and ext has been defined as a org.eclipse.team.cvs.core.connectionmethods extension point. How come extssh is not defined any where?

(In reply to comment #0) > I see that cvs pserver and ext has been defined as a > org.eclipse.team.cvs.core.connectionmethods extension point. > How come extssh is not defined any where?
It has been defined in org.eclipse.team.cvs.ssh2 plug-in's plugin.xml.
I only see 'ssh2' and 'pserverssh2' in org.eclipse.team.cvs.ssh2 plugin. But not 'extssh'. (Based on Eclipse 3.2)

(In reply to comment #2) > I only see 'ssh2' and 'pserverssh2' in org.eclipse.team.cvs.ssh2 plugin. > But not 'extssh'. (Based on Eclipse 3.2)
'ssh2' corresponds to 'extssh'. Refer to http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/org.eclipse.team.cvs.ssh2/src/org/eclipse/team/internal/ccvs/ssh2/CVSSSH2Method.java?rev=HEAD&content-type=text/vnd.viewcvs-markup

Suggesting to separate core runtime component for org.eclipse.team.cvs.ssh2 and its UI required component. Such that importing from extssh CVS repository won't require to load SWT.
FYI, The Eclipse product I am working on is trying to drive eclipse build funtions without requiring the GUI.
Importing from a extssh CVS repository is a requirement.

I'm sorry for my delay of reponding to you.
(In reply to comment #4) > Suggesting to separate core runtime component for org.eclipse.team.cvs.ssh2 and > its UI required component. > Such that importing from extssh CVS repository won't require to load SWT. > FYI, The Eclipse product I am working on is trying to drive eclipse build > funtions without requiring the GUI. > Importing from a extssh CVS repository is a requirement.
In other point of view, I also think that the current implementation of org.eclipse.team.cvs.ssh2(CVS-SSH2) plug-in should be changed.
That plug-in is using ssh2 client JSch[1] and including a wrapper class[2], which will cache ssh2 sessions and have re-connecting mechanism at unexpected session drop, etc. and preference pages[3], which depened on SWT.
You may know that Eclipse.org's DSDP(Device Software Development Platform) project has been using JSch and they have also implemented a wrapper class and preference pages for ssh2 setting. I think it must be reinvent of wheel. In the near future, other plug-ins (including Subversion plug-in) may need ssh2 functionality and they will also implement their own wrapper class and preference pages for ssh2. It should not happen, IMHO.
So, I'm thinking that yet another plug-ins(for example, org.eclipse.jsch.core and org.eclipse.jsch.ui) should exist and it should include a wrapper class and preferences. CVS-SSH2 plug-in and a plug-in under DSDP should refer to that plug-in.
How do you think of this idea?
[1] http://www.jcraft.com/jsch/ [2] org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.ssh2.JSchSession class [3] org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.ssh2.CVSSSH2PreferencePage class

(In reply to comment #5) > In the near future, other plug-ins (including Subversion plug-in) may > need ssh2 functionality and they will also implement their own wrapper class > and preference pages for ssh2. It should not happen, IMHO.
Both existing Subversion plugins are using Ganymed SSH library [1]. That is what used by javasvn from TMate [2], which at some point migrated from jssh to Ganymed, saying that they've got nicer API and more stable implementation.
So, if jssh is going to be widely used by Eclipse platform, it would be really good idea to pay some attention to the jssh API.
[1] http://sourceforge.net/projects/ganymedssh2/ [2] http://tmate.org/svn/

Interesting info.
Anyway, I just hope the core runtime implementation don't need to pull in any UI/swt library. :)

(In reply to comment #6) > Both existing Subversion plugins are using Ganymed SSH library [1]. That is > what used by javasvn from TMate [2], which at some point migrated from jssh to > Ganymed
Yes, it is right and javasvn has still a mechanism to switch back to use jsch. In fact, with a quick hack for the latest Subversive plug-in, I could do svn+ssh access by jsch.

(In reply to comment #8) > Yes, it is right and javasvn has still a mechanism to switch back to use jsch. > In fact, with a quick hack for the latest Subversive plug-in, I could do > svn+ssh access by jsch.
Nice. But what that would buy you?

(In reply to comment #7) > Interesting info. > Anyway, I just hope the core runtime implementation don't need to pull in any > UI/swt library. :)
I don't hesitate to change that plug-in for your requirement. I think the easy fix is to move CVSSSH2PreferencePage.java to org.eclipse.team.cvs.ui plug-in, but it will add the dependency for jsch to org.eclipse.team.cvs.ui. So, org.eclipse.team.cvs.ssh2 should be changed to org.eclipse.team.cvs.ssh2.core and org.eclipse.team.cvs.ssh2.ui , but I don't have any privileges to create new plug-in on Eclipse.org. How do you think, TEAM, CVS comitters?

bug.short_desc: [Dialogs] Restore dialog contents / Control Dialog's disposing

long_desc.thetext: When having complex dialogs it is nice when dialog pops up the next time dialog's old state is restored. The simplest method to get to this feature is to not dispose the dialog area but only setting the shell's visiblity false.
Created an attachment (id=46683) Patch to make this work by setting flag

Created an attachment (id=46695) Fix problem with blocking dialogs not returning from open
This patch adds the possibility to close dialogs which are running in block mode my setting a flag to exit the event-loop and returning from the open-call.

I don't see the need to add new API to support this feature. The existing API and description of the life-cycle of dialogs has been long-standing. Clients who wish to preserve dialog state have many different options for doing so. The most common pattern I've seen is retaining the instance of the dialog (thus preserving the data values), allowing the dialog to be disposed, and repopulating the content when the dialog controls are recreated. Simply hiding the shell leaves many window instances (and platform window handles) lying around and I wouldn't want to promote this at the framework level.
That said, you can still implement your desired behavior in your own dialogs.

The problem is that you don't give people a chance todo that their own because the method runEventLoop(Shell loopShell) is private and you need to copy the whole code. Would be a possibility to make this protected so subclasses could overload it?

I wouldn't want to open up the framework to encourage the overriding of the event loop. This seems like a subtle change that provides a hook for lifecycle changes that the framework was not designed for.
If you really want to change the lifecycle, I think you should make it as explicit as possible. I think you'd be better off overriding open to trigger your own event loop method. Copy the code that makes sense and add your own flags for visibility, etc.
Overriding the open method also allows you to document your changes in the life-cycle, since you are effectively changing the contract of the API. I still see this approach as semi-dangerous...ie, how do you decide when to actually dispose the dialog, how many dialogs are left open over the course of your app, etc. etc..., but that is your call.
At any rate, I think this is something you can implement without any extra hooks.

attachment.desc: Patch to make this work by setting flag
Fix problem with blocking dialogs not returning from open

After investigating the cause of this defect, it's clear that this regression is prevalent in many large use cases. Upgrading the severity accordingly.
Will attach a patch file with the fix and lobby for 4.2.1 inclusion.

Created an attachment (id=47840) Patch file for fix to 151525
Wraps EMFUtil.save() in a WorkspaceRunnable and corrects the OPTIONS passed by SaveManager

Some details for the evaluation of this defect in 4.2.1:
The symptoms of this defect are that, any time a caller saves an instance of any of the test models and does not wrap that save call in a WorkspaceRunnable/WorkspaceModifyOperation/WorkspaceJob, and if the resulting serialized file is larger than 256K, you will get exceptions logged (both to the eclipse log, and also potentially in pop-up dialogs, depending on the caller). These exceptions will happen once every 256K, until the file is completely saved. It is very prominently user visible.
The fix is to wrap the EMFUtil.save method in an IWorkspaceRunnable, which makes the write operation appear atomic to the workspace (as it was prior to 4.2.) While it's true that callers could individually wrap their save calls in an IWorkspaceRunnable, some of those callers are within TPTP itself, and the need to wrap the save call was introduced with the fix to a different critical defect in 4.2.1 (and thus it would be a behavior change to require the caller to do this.)
Fixed in HEAD and 4.2.1
ACTION: Please verify/close this defect.

bug.short_desc: Allow DataExtractionTask to extract inner table by instance ID

long_desc.thetext:
Fixes to Bug 145691 had the side effect of disabling export of inner query (included subquery and nested query) altogether. This however is not correct. There are many valid use cases where an inner query's data needs to be exported.
Engine's IDataExtractionTask should have the following behavior: (1) getResultSetList() returns only the master result sets (this is the current behavior) (2) If setInstanceID() is called with the ID of a result set, the extract() method should extract that result set, regardless of whether the instance ID identifies a master, nested query or subquery result set.

Fixed.
If using the InstanceId to export data and the query is not a master query, the filters which have been set to DataExtractionTask will not effect.
For the filter problem of exporting data with InstanceId.
Support filter now when using InstanceId to export data.

bug.short_desc: Parameters in SQL query causes error

long_desc.thetext:
Use of ? in Dataset's Qery editor causes an error. using '?' solves the editing problem, however the query will not wotk any more. The only work around is to use '?' and hit close the window, then change '?' to ? within the property-editor. This has been tested for DateTime fields Example query:
Select * from race_runs where start_time > ?
This has worked in 2.01

If you find no problem about the "?" please provide your report design which can reproduce the bug in your machine.
Thanks.

I've reported a bug to mysql. You can trace it from http://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=21267. Thanks!
I wonder why i can change the sql in property editor without having this problem

In property editor, it will not retrieve the parameter metadata from driver, so the error does not exist. From deep investigation, I think we should not stop user's following operation just because there is unexpected exception thrown by JDBC Driver. So when there is exception in retrieving parameter metadata, we will encapsule the unexpected exception in JDBCException, which will never stop the user's other operation.

bug.short_desc: Undo contributes should remove link in the diagram

long_desc.thetext:
1.Create two CPs: CP1, CP2 2.In CP1, create three activities: A1, A2, A3. And link them as follows: A1 ------> A2 -----> A3 2.Extend CP1 into CP2. Make A3 'Local Contribution'. 3.Draw a link from A1 to A3. Goto WBS and 'undo contribute to Activity' on A3. ---->Problem: Link between A1 and A3 hasn't been removed, and the AD editor doesn't get closed.
Expected Result: 1. Undo contributes should remove link in the diagram 2.The editor will close when undo contributes is done 3. Reopen the AD editor to verify if the original AD is restored after 'undo contribution'.
*** Bug 151544 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Please verify whether those issues are valid.
Tushara has check this again and reported: in M4, when I 'undo contributes', the link is removed though editor is not closed. So it is not really a bug.
Mark this bug as INVALID per developer's comments
invalid bug

bug.short_desc: Standalone Java profiling usage info conflicts with Getting Started documentation

long_desc.thetext:
"Getting Started with Agent Controller - Windows" says "file=filename\nSpecifies the name of a file where the trace will be written. The default is trace.xml in the current directory." Meanwhile "java -XrunpiAgent:help" which that doc says I can do gives me "file=<file>\t\tName of output file. Only used when server=standalone.(\ntrace.trcxml)" trace.xml or trace.trcxml?? Which is it? trace.trcxml, as the :help output says; the Getting Started document is wrong.
Note further that the online help lists a lot of agent_parms not documented on the Getting Started page. That might be good, as "mode=full", per the :help output, results in "Bad PIAgent option"! ditto for modes sampling and noObjectCorrelation... I stopped tryign at this point.

Reassigning to Dale for the changes to the Getting Started page for the agent controller.
For the on-line help changes (documented options do not work on Windows agent controller), I don't know if that is part of the outstanding work that remains to be done. (e.g. I believe that the new agent controller doesn't support the IAC yet.) Adding Harm and Karla as cc to this email so that they can comment on the plans; if it's established that these changes need to be made, then I believe that Dale is responsible for the Windows copy of the agent controller documentation and would make those changes also.

The piAgent can use IAC through backwards compatibility mode on Windows - that is fully supported. The gaps are in the use of agents for the new API, so it is unrelated to anything in this bug report.
If there is a discrepancy between what the piAgent's usage message claims and what the piAgent actually allows, then there is a bug in the piAgent and that should be filed in a separate bug report. Copying Bob regarding this aspect.
The error in the getting started guide exists in the RAC version and AC version, since the AC pulled the profiling info from the RAC version. Dale will change the getting_started_ac.html, but we don't plan to maintain the old RAC version getting_started.html. We should probably eliminate the RAC version of this file in 4.3, by checking in getting_started_ac.html over the top of the existing getting_started.html (then deleting _ac version) so that we don't lose the history of the original.

We won;t be able to retire the getting started RAC material until we retire the RAC which seems to be a long way away. On Windows we have to deal with the fact that we don't have a clean story for the end user. IAC uses the RAC, but local separate process profiling uses the AC. This technology issue should be transparent to the user, including the config file. We have had discussions in the past on the importance of the user view of this and hwo to configure things. In 4.3 we need to at least make this all look like one thing. There are separate issues specific to the TI agent which I think is the only shipping agent that uses the new AC directly. We need to think of 4.3 as a stabliizing and consistency release.

This fix does need to be applied to every platform version of the Agent Controller Getting Started guides, both RAC and AC. In comment #2 I meant that for the Windows version of the getting started guide, we should only maintain the AC version and retire the RAC version which it replaced in 4.2, but did not overwrite in the cvs repository.
Dale, Hendra handled all the getting started guide changes in 4.2 except for the Windows version. Please coordinate with Bob if this is to be fixed in 4.2.1, else with Samson if it is to be done in 4.3.
Changed target milestone to agree with other doc assignments.
I have updated the Getting Started docs to ref trace.trcxml and so I believe this defect can now be resolved as fixed.
I added the change to the windows version in the new AC's getting started doc, so that's all of them. Marking as fixed.
Moving bugs from Trace.Doc to Platform.Doc because Trace.Doc will be removed.

bug.short_desc: Select Existing service doesn't sort results properly

long_desc.thetext: If the search pattern on the Select Existing Dialog returns a number of results, the exact match is often way way down the list. And the results aren't really sorted alphabetically.

Created an attachment (id=48179) Patch
Previously, the list was being sorted using the full display name of each object. Now the list is sorted using the name only, which gives a more meaningful sort.
committed

bug.short_desc: [validation] Multiple validation jobs run at same time

long_desc.thetext: I've noticed, esppecially when large projects imported, that a large number of validation jobs all start at "same time" to do their work so each validator ends up working "at the same time" as the others. I do not think this really improves UI responsiveness or performance, but I suspect it greatly increases the probability of threading problems or deadlocks. I think only one "validation job" should run at a time, and it just manage and "feed" one validator at a time. Overall perforamnce and responsiveness would be the same, but contention and locking would be much less, IMHO.

By all starting at the same time, the validators enter into a race and negatively impact underlying model caches. Namely, different validators can work on the same artifact *minutes* apart. No scalable cache can keep models that long in memory (we have seen caches grow to 1GB when we tried to cover the wide window validators currently cover). Validators that are known to work on the same artifact should be synchronized and triggered from one loop/job.
In addition to the above issue, the mere fact of generating many jobs makes Eclipse choke while trying to update its progress view. When a validation is performed on a large project, opening the Progress View easily slows down the validation by 25%. See bug 160941.
I suggest to have one single validator job that dispatches all work and does not create any other jobs. The deltaSet of files that have to be validated should be sorted such that validators with the short queue get a chance to finish first.

Some small amount of concurrency may actually be faster than a single job. I.e., when one job is blocked on I/O another could continue validating. However, the amount of concurrent jobs needed to get this benefit would be on the order of two or three, rather than the dozens that may be launched with the current one job per validator instance approach.

bug.short_desc: Options to disable synthetic IDs.

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, the Hibernate mapping generator creates synthetic IDs for EClasses without a primary key. However, cascading updates to detached objects using a Hibernate SessionFactory does not (always?) work correctly when with synthetic ID, but does work correctly when using a genuine primary key.
There should be an option to disable the generation of synthetic IDs, so as to notify the user a genuine primary key should be created. The default behaviour may be confusing.
The issue of cascading updates with synthetic id's has been solved (see elver mailing list).

This is not a big issue as synthetic id's are only used in case someone did not specify an id property, it is very unlikely that this really happens and if you remember such a proposed option then you would certainly remember to have synthetic id's (or not).

bug.short_desc: Add support for lazy="extra" (hibernate) collection attribute

long_desc.thetext:
Support for hibernate lazy="extra" has been committed to cvs, the FetchType annotation has been extended with a value EXTRA.
Some extra remarks related to hibernate extra-lazy support:
I tested it for a list (so not for bag or map). The size() and get() methods are lazy (no loading of the complete list). Also the contains method should be lazy. However the add and remove methods are not lazy. So the extra-lazy makes sense if you update the list very infrequently but do a lot of get calls.
With this in mind I am not sure if the extra-lazy is the real solution for extremely large lists. For this scenario the best approach probably is to make the list-feature transient and have a reference from the child to the parent. Adding to the list is then setting the parent in the child. When the list needs to be read as a whole this can be done through a query.

bug.short_desc: "Invalid Thread Access" when Generator.build() called from non-UI thread

long_desc.thetext:
The likely reason being that besides calling methods of org.eclipse.swt.graphics.GC, methods on org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display are also called, which is not allowed in a non-UI thread.
=====
Here's the discussion from the newsgroup:
David,
- The "Invalid Thread Access" happens for us too, with BIRT 2.1 (LATEST). - Oddly, it didn't happen for us with BIRT 2.0
The stacktrace is below. Here's my take why it happens (I should probably enter bug report): Suppose we have 2 threads, - the regular UI thread - worker thread calling the Generator.build()
Now: 1. GENERALLY, SWT does allow painting (or measuring stuff) with a GC from a second thread: this means: you CAN call ANY method of GC from within a worker thread. 2. BUT: You cannot create a new GC instance from the second thread like this: "new GC(display)" because this construction calls methods of object display.
The reason? - The "display" object which is passed is actually a "widget", and so the widget rules apply: calling its methods can only be done from the thread where it was created (i.e. our UI thread). This applies to calls such as "new GC(display)", display.getDPI() (Ivo's problem), and in fact to all the methods of class Display.
Options? - One option is to do new Display() from within the 2nd worker thread, but this only works on Windows. - Another option is to do the a) "new GC(display)", b) display.getXXX() in the UI thread, like the following pattern:
in Generator.build():
Display display = Display.getCurrent(); GC gc; if(display == null) { // Bad, no display for this thread => we are not in (a) UI thread display.syncExec(new Runnable() {void run() { gc = new GC(display);}}); } else { gc = new GC(display); }
OR:
Display display = Display.getCurrent(); int dpi; if(display == null) { // Bad, no display for this thread => we are not in (a) UI thread display.syncExec(new Runnable() {void run() { dpi = display.getDPI();}}); } else { dpi = display.getDPI(); }
Needless to say this will only work if the UI thread spins the message loop, and it is best if everything you need from the display is taken at one step. Probably you should also bug the SWT devs to explain you all the intricasies of using GC from within worker thread.
Ivan
P.S. The stacktrace:

bug.short_desc: Add the ability to get the resource URI with EMF repository

long_desc.thetext:
When generating a weaving model, it is a shame that we are not able to get the models resources URIs. This patch enable it in a similar way to allInstances() operation. If you do MM!Element.resourceURI() you will get the metamodel resource URI If you do MM!Element.resourceURIOf("model_name") you will get model resource URI It is a quick and dirty hack but it works :D
This patch apply to org.atl.engine.repositories.emf4atl/ASMModelElement.java
It has been tested with the latest CVS version of ATL.
Regards, Mikal
Created an attachment (id=46701) Patch for org.atl.engine.repositories.emf4atl\src\org\atl\engine\repositories\emf4atl\ASMEMFModelElement
Closed as WONTFIX

bug.short_desc: Null-pointer exception in generated ?VisualIDRegistry.getLinkWithClassVisualID(EObject domainElement)

long_desc.thetext:
Generated ?VisualIDRegistry.getLinkWithClassVisualID(EObject domainElement) method throws null-pointer exception if domainElement == null.
Return -1 should if null passed instead of domainElement.

bug.short_desc: Diagram labels {elementicon=true} should share Image instances

long_desc.thetext:
Actually if gmfgraph.DiagramLabel has elementIcon=true, generated code creates separate org.eclipse.swt.graphics.Image instances for each label. These images are never disposed.
As reported at news:0c53dd0163f15de5f9457c00b26b87c3$1@www.eclipse.org, it forces generated code to fail in run-time with SWT "No More Handles" error even with relatively small diagrams (400 top-level elements, 5000 inner labels).
Expected: generated code should use ImageRegistry trying to obtain images for diagram labels. Thus, diagram with, say, 20000 of labels of same kind should be opened without handle problems.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 156362 ***

bug.short_desc: Make registered buddy policy accept non-dependent bundles or define new policy

long_desc.thetext:
The history behind the registered buddy policy was to provide a way to scope the dependent policy down to a specific set of bundles instead of using the complete set of dependent bundles. This is why the registed policy only uses a subset of dependent bundles. It has become evident that some scenarios require a buddy policy where the buddies have no dependency on the bundle they want to be a buddy for.
We should consider changing the registered policy to accept non-dependent bundles or we should add a new policy that is similar to registered but allows for non-dependent bundles. I'm in favor of changing the registered policy. This would not break existing bundles that use the registered policy, they would still work fine. But it would allow additional bundles to become buddies that do not have a dependency on the bundle they want to be a buddy for.
What about uncommenting the code allowing people to create their own policy?

If I have three plugins A, B, and C A's manifest includes: Eclipse-BuddyPolicy: registered B depends on A and exports the dependancy like: Require-Bundle: A;visibility:=reexport C depends on B and therefore depends implicitly on A. C's manifest includes: Eclipse-RegisterBuddy: A
A still cannot load classes from C. It is as if C was not registered as a buddy of A. The workaround: explicitly make C depend on A. It is redundant, but then A can load classes from C.

(In reply to comment #2)
Can you open a separate bug to track this and attach a testcase to reproduce. Thanks.

(In reply to comment #3) > (In reply to comment #2) > > Can you open a separate bug to track this and attach a testcase to reproduce. > Thanks. >
See Bug 197887

bug.short_desc: [scripting] Allow for the result of a refactoring to be applied without the refactoring

long_desc.thetext:
It would be nice if the refactoring script functionality would allow for the result of a refactoring to be applied but not require the original input to be in a prerefactored state. The use case for this is a project refactors their API for the next release. With the new release they send out a refactoring script to allow consumers to update their code to work with the refactored API.
Currently if a refactoring is attempted where the input is already refactored the refactoring will not be applied. The framework sees that it has already occurred and the consumer is left with their code referencing the old API.

See bug 139730 for the use case.
As already described in bug 139730, Java refactorings do only work on workspaces which compile. This cannot be the case in scenarios mentioned in your request. How eg. should the framework decide for a rename type refactoring what to do if the input type already exists? Does that mean the refactoring has already taken place, or there simply is an already existing type with the same name? This fundamental problem cannot be solved in general.
Bug 139730 describes the process of automatically refactoring a project which has been added to the workspace after some refactoring.
Closing as wont fix.

(In reply to comment #1) > How eg. should the framework decide for a rename type refactoring > what to do if the input type already exists? Does that mean the refactoring has > already taken place, or there simply is an already existing type with the same > name? This fundamental problem cannot be solved in general.
It doesn't have to be solved generally. If it was part of the wizard the consumer could make the decision as they know why they have the script and its intent. Inform the user and let us make those decisions.
> Bug 139730 describes the process of automatically refactoring a project which > has been added to the workspace after some refactoring.
This will only work if you have access to the source and this isn't always the case.

bug.short_desc: Problem generating variables references in HOT (Ecore2ATL)

long_desc.thetext:
A bug appear in the new CVS version of ATL/AM3 (it already worked 3 weeks ago). In a HOT, in order to make reference to a variable, i have to create a VariableExp like this :
thisModuleVar : ATL!VariableExp ( referredVariable <- thisModuleVarDecl )
Every uses of this kind of construct results in blank with Ecore2ATL. The generated ATL model (.ecore) is correct but the extraction in ATL concrete syntax fails.
First example: I'd like to create a call to "thisModule.mymodel" global variable
thisModuleVarDecl : ATL!VariableDeclaration ( varName <- 'thisModule' ), thisModuleVar : ATL!VariableExp ( referredVariable <- thisModuleVarDecl ), stmt_model_source : ATL!NavigationOrAttributeCallExp ( name <- 'mymodel', source <- thisModuleVar )
The results after serialization : ".model" without the "thisModule" before the dot.
Second example: I'd like to do a binding between a variable in a SimpleOutPatternElement and another SimpleOutPatternElement like this (this is what i expected) :
model: MM!Model( name <- 'mymodel', aModelRef <- outModelRef ), outModelRef: MM!ModelRef( name <- 'mymodelref' )
For this i did : [...] opeModel_leftModel : ATL!Binding ( propertyName <- 'aModelRef', value <- opeaModelRef_var ), [...] opeaModelRef : ATL!SimpleOutPatternElement ( varName <- 'outModelRef', bindings <- Sequence{[...]}, type <- [...] ), opeaModelRef_var : ATL!VariableExp ( referredVariable <- opeaModelRef ) [...]
But i get this:
model: MM!Model( name <- 'mymodel', aModelRef <- ), outModelRef: MM!ModelRef( name <- 'mymodelref' )
despite the ATL model is also correct from this point of view (everything is well referenced etc.) It must come from the Ecore2ATL extractor (i think).
Sorry for the lack of patch :/
Regards, Mikal
Bug corrected. There was a problem in the TCS of ATL when using "OclUndefinedExp" and "VariableExp" elements. We replaced it with a correct version.

bug.short_desc: resource names cannot contain certain characters

long_desc.thetext:
TPTP LocationPage class calls org.eclipse.hyades.ui.internal.util.UIUtil::validateOSFileName to validate that the file name does not contain certain set of characters. One of the characters is '#' and therefore it is impossible to create a Hyades resource with '#' in its name. It is possible however to modify a test so that its name contains '#' which is invalid for TPTP/EMF/XML but IS valid character for the OS.
The org.eclipse.hyades.ui.internal.util.UIUtil validation methods are incorrect because the make cerain assumtions about OS validation rules. In fact many of the characters blocked by those methods ARE valid in some operatng systems. So, IMHO, these methods need to be fixed. The right way to validate names in Eclipse is to use IWorkspace and IPath.
In addition, because the '#' char is invalid from TPTP/EMF/XML point of view, TPTP needs to provide a utility method to validate resource names (which are not the same as file or path names).
===== State: Assigned by:amathur at 7/20/2006 8:16:40 PM =====
It all boils down to having a # in the path to the file. I fixed the model code where it was originally failing. After that fix, now it fails in the test creation wizard code. We need to flag an error in the wizard if we see a '#' in the path. The same applies to the 'Test from Recording wizard' that comes from TPTP. Re-assigning it to Alex to see what we can do.
===== State: Submitted by:ademuyser at 7/18/2006 2:47:13 PM =====
****Description field information .**** Create a new Test Project named "ReallyFrom Sc@tc#", Select File > New > Others... Then choose Test > Test Assets > New HTTP Test, select created project, enter a name for test suite (my_http). Hit Finish button.
Test suite is not created, Error Log displays:

Reassign to Jerome.

This should not delay the test pass, however would be desirable to fix in 4.2.1 if it can be contained.
Specific issue is simply the fact that the HTTP recorder allows # sign in file path.

Retargetting to 4.3 after discussion during the test meeting.
Allowing those special characters in name or path may cause TPTP not working when it uses the getPath() method rather than the getString(). We should choose the best strategy for the naming of TPTP elements: being platform dependant by using IPath validation or listing some forbidden characters?

Created an attachment (id=51929) Patch to be committed once i3 is opened
The LocationValidator class in org.eclipse.hyades.ui.util (the one from org.eclipse.tptp.platform.common.ui plugin) has been created. This will give access to TPTP location validation method for downstream products.
The list of banned characters have also been updated regarding the syntax defined by RFC 2396 (see http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2396.txt ) Here are the list of banned character for our resource naming because they are reserved, escaped or unwise characters: ;/?:@&=+$,"<>% and {}|\^[]`
Comparing with the previous list, the following characters are now authorized characters (because I do not find any good reasons to forbid it): '~!* Note that those two latter characters still banned on windows platform but will be allowed on Unixes. There are five new forbidden characters: @&$%^
The patch contains also the validation of the container path (so the bug 101308 will be fixed indirectly).

Providing this capability will require a huge test phasis to cover all the TPTP components, that is why I open bug 160861 to track that for a future version. bug.short_desc: [implementation] DefaultPositionUpdater is not exclusive when end offset gets replaced

long_desc.thetext: This was changed when DefaultPositionUpdater.isAffectingReplace() was introduced.

Fixed > 20060804 and enabled the test.
The corner case in question is:
document: "ccccccccccccccccc" position(5+5): [___] replace (9,2,2): "cccccccccyycccccc" updated position: [____] (from R1.6 to R1.12) updated position: [__] (previous and new behavior)
previously, this resulted in the position being expanded to (5+6). However, the javadoc of DefaultPositionUpdater states that "Replacing text overlapping with the position is considered as a sequence of first deleting the replaced text and afterwards inserting the new text." Respecting this rule first shrinks the position to (5+4) and does not expand it afterwards.

bug.short_desc: [WorkbenchParts] SaveablesList not unregistering my part

long_desc.thetext:
I own the somewhat currently unsupported situation of an editor embedded into a view. My view implements ISaveablePart2 and so when it is opened and PartList.partOpened() is called and calls out to modelManager.postOpen(actualPart); , my part ( a view ) get registered in the SaveablesList registery with a DefaultSaveable object.
When my view gets closed, through closing the view or closing the perspective it is not getting removed from this registry. The PartList.partClosed() method does not have an equivalent call out to modelManager.postClose(actualPart); and because my part is not an editor the postClose method does not get invoked anywhere else either.
So I have a memory leak.
Currently to get around this I have hacked the following into my view dispose method.....
SaveablesList saveablesList = (SaveablesList)getSite(). getService(ISaveablesLifecycleListener.class); Object postCloseInfo = saveablesList.preCloseParts(Collections .singletonList(this), true, this.getSite() .getWorkbenchWindow()); saveablesList.postClose(postCloseInfo);
This works but I have the Discouraged Access warning all over these lines of code.

Thanks a lot for tracking down and reporting this bug! This may even cause data loss and must be fixed for 3.2.1.
BTW, instead of implementing ISaveablePart2 in your case it might be worth looking at implementing ISaveablesSource.
I can only reproduce this when you close the last perspective showing a view that implements ISaveablePart2.
Created an attachment (id=47987) patch
Released to HEAD >20060815.

Released into R3_2_maintenance for M20060816-0800.
Marking as fixed. If possible, please try the maintenance build and verify that the bug is indeed fixed. Please reopen if you find another code path that leads to a leak of the same sort.
Paul, could you please review the patch? When closing a perspective, views that implement ISaveablePart were not unregistered from the (internal) SaveablesList, creating at least a memory leak.

In WorkbenchPage#closePerspective(*), is it possible to get to // closeAllEditors already notified the saveables list about the editors. without having gone through the editor save mechanism?
If we skipped editor save, should we still try and save viewsToClose?
PW

(In reply to comment #7) > In WorkbenchPage#closePerspective(*), is it possible to get to > // closeAllEditors already notified the saveables list about the editors. > without having gone through the editor save mechanism?
Yes, if the argument saveEditors is false.
> If we skipped editor save, should we still try and save viewsToClose?
Saving is done earlier (the call to EditorManager.saveAll), which is also the place where the user has a chance to cancel. Only after we know that the user didn't cancel the close can we proceed and close the parts: First the editors, if it was the last perspective of this page, and then the views with reference count of one.

(In reply to comment #8) > Saving is done earlier (the call to EditorManager.saveAll), which is also the > place where the user has a chance to cancel. Only after we know that the user > didn't cancel the close can we proceed and close the parts: First the editors, > if it was the last perspective of this page, and then the views with reference > count of one.
But if we skipped the editor save, then we don't call EditorManager#saveAll(*). Is it not still valid to save any views that are closing with a reference == 1?
Or do we only support saving the views if we can also save the editors?
PW

> Or do we only support saving the views if we can also save the editors?
We only save the views if saveEditors is true. There are some callers who take care of the saving themselves, and they pass saveEditors=false. Normally, I would expect clients to pass in true.

Thanks :-)

bug.short_desc: Provide public API to determine if a PointcutExpression tests based on runtime type of 'this'

long_desc.thetext:
In the weaver.tools API, there is no way to determine what runtime tests will be executed when a ShadowMatch returns maybeMatches(). Spring needs to know whether the this, target, @this, @target, or @annotation vars are part of the runtime test, because if so it can make an important optimisation in Spring AOP to say that the pointcut does not match. This is because the exact runtime type of a bean is already known - there can never be a subsitute subtype later on. The Spring class org.springframework.aop.aspectj.RuntimeTestWalker contains an ugly workaround for AspectJ not providing this API.
The smallest needed additional external API would be to add an operation
boolean matchConditionalOnRuntimeTypeOfThis()
to the ShadowMatch interface.
Spring code can be cleaned up once this enhancement is incorporated...

bug.short_desc: A more flexible CVS support would be really appreciated...

long_desc.thetext:
This is just a request for enhancement that will be trashed, I think... Anyway, after using Eclipse for over a year, and after making DOZEN of trials, I felt I had to try to publish this request.
CVS support in Eclipse is excellent as soon as you do things in a well defined way: you check out your projects using Eclipse (given that this project is in a well defined folder in the CVS repository) and, even better, you start to share a new project from within Eclipse itself (creating a new CVS module or folder), so that the .project file is copied to the CVS repository too.
But it is VERY limited as soon as: 1) you have some previous code in your CVS that you want to checkout into your own (and maybe already existing) project, which might be a Java project, a J2EE project, etc.; you have to use the function "check out into an existing project" which behaves a little strange and have some limits (for instance: it seems to make a "hidden" link between your project and the HEAD tag, even if the root folder of your project is not phisically in the repository... and the checked out files are stored into a different branch, not HEAD...) 2) you have different files in different branches BUT within the same CVS folder: I know this is a quite strange way to use the CVS, but suppose you have a huge folder with thousands of source files and you started to modularize them by tagging different files with different branches... When you do "check out into an existing folder", you cannot check out into two different folders of the same project some files that come from the SAME CVS folder BUT from different branches: maybe the hidden link I previously mentioned between the root folder of the project and the HEAD tag is the source of troubles... 3) you use some ANT scripts to check out source files from different branches and merge them into the same local folder: suppose you are developing a webapp with WTP and you are limited to have the WebContent files (JSPs, HTMLs, etc.) into an only folder, but you have the JSPs in different CVS branches, because they are modularized in that way... Using an ANT script you may check out things and merge them into the only WebContent folder. Using a common CVS client, you are able to manage those "merged" files from different branches locally stored into the same folder, but then you can't import the result into your Eclipse project in any way, if you want to use its internal CVS client to synchronize... you are forced to use an external CVS client
Some results can be achieved by creating different projects and setting dependencies from one another, maybe using linked folders in the classpath and other dirty tricks... Anyway, this is cumbersome and there are a lot of drawbacks (for instance, think of the possibility to have circular dependencies between two or more projects...).
Some other examples could be done to outline how difficult is to import into Eclipse something which is locally stored under version control, if you want (or hope...) to use Eclipse internal CVS client to manage it... except, as I said, when you check out things directly from the CVS server with Eclipse itself and you are so lucky to have a well organized CVS server.
In my particular experience, I work together with people using NetBeans (well: the main project we are working on was born with NetBeans, while Eclipse has started to be used just last year) and they have no problems to import local folders under version control and to use NetBeans internal CVS client to manage them... NetBeans simply recognize such folders as "under version control" and gives you all the options to commit, update and compare things straight away...
Eclipse support, instead, is something given "out-of-the-box" and suffers from the problems I outlined before. This is the main reason for which it has not yet been adopted by many people in my organization.
Is there any hope to have a more flexible CVS support in future Eclipse versions?
I hope my English is good enough to make you understand my point of view :-)
Mauro.

We just don't have the manpower to work on such a specialized request. Really, the best person to implement these types of specialized features is the person (or people) who require them. We would be happy to provide help if you wanted to undergo this task. If you think there are others that may have similar problems, you may want to post your thoughts on the eclipse-platform newsgroup to see if others are interested in helping out.

Ok Michael, I'd just like to add that this request doesn't seem so "specialized" to me... I think it should be better called a step towards a standard CVS client compliant model and towards interoperability with other IDEs. I'll try the newsgroup, as you suggest.
Mauro.

Your point is valid. For better or worse, the current CVS support evolved from the desire to support a particular work flow and not from a desire to work like the standard command line CVS. We have done work to try and support more diversified work flows but, as you suggest, we do not have complete coverage. Unfortunately, we do not have enough manpower to continue on this path. However, we are happy to help out anyone who wishes to improve the Eclipse CVS client through the contribution of patches.

bug.short_desc: Enhanced support for WLS 8.1 and 9.0 generic adapters

long_desc.thetext:
+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #149215 +++
Due to issues surrounding backward compatibility, the enhanced wldeploy-based publish functionality was not added to 8.1 and 9.0 versions for 1.5.1 (they are auto-deploy based).
The required serverdef files are attached to this bugzilla for users that want to locally modify their 8.1 and 9.0 WLS adapters to use the new functionality.
IMPORTANT: Doing this will:
-break existing WLS 8.1 and 9.0 generic server instance definitions (they will need to be deleted and recreated) -modules currently deployed to the server via the old server adapters should be undeployed prior to deployment via the new adapters (the autodeployment mechanism uses a different module name and can result in clashes)
Instructions for adding the updated 8.1/9.0 serverdef files:
-Make certain you are using a 1.5.1 build that includes the changes from tag v200607241119 -Undeploy all modules currently deployed via old 8.1/9.0 server adapter instances -Delete all existing 8.1/9.0 server adapter instances -Shutdown Eclipse -Rename the weblogic81/90.serverdef files currently in the directory eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.jst.server.generic.weblogic_<version>/servers -Copy the new weblogic81/90.serverdef files to the directory eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.jst.server.generic.weblogic_<version>/servers -Restart Eclipse
